titleStmt.title: Inscription in honour of Arcadius from Aphrodisias by Tatianus praet. praefect

availability.licence: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

summary.term: Honorary inscription to the emperor Arcadius

layout.rs: Fragmentary. Five lines of the inscription have been deliberately effaced.

history.provenance: Aphrodisias, South Agora, center of the West stoa (in front of entrance to the courtyard of the Hadrianic Baths)

div.ab:
ἀγαθῆι τύχηι·
τὸν τῆς ὑφ’ ἡλίῳ γῆς αὐτοκράτορα
καὶ τροπεοῦχον δεσπότην ἡμῶν
Φλάουιον Ἀρκάδιον τὸν αἰώνιον Αὔγουστον,
Φλάουιος Εὐτόλμιος Τατιανὸς ὀ λαμπρότατος ἔπαρχος
τοῦ ἱερου πρετωρίου τῇ συνήθει
καθοσιώσει ἀφιέρωσεν,
ἐπὶ Ἀντωνίου Πρίσκου
τοῦ λαμπροτάτου ἡγεμόνος.

app.note: [Ἀγαθῆι] Mendel; line omitted by Grégoire; Ἀ[γαθῇ] Boulanger, Robert.
ff. Grégoire was unaware of this erasure. Mendel saw three erased lines, followed by another two, as did Roueché; Boulanger recorded three erased lines, and read ΟΣ at the end of l.5.

div.p: “Alla Sorte propizia! All’imperatore della Terra sotto il sole, e nostro vittorioso signore, Flavius Arcadius l’eterno Augusto, Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus, il chiarissimo prefetto del sacro pretorio con la consueta devozione consacrò (la statua), mentre era chiarissimo governatore Antonius Priscus.”

“May Fortune be propitious! To the emperor of (all) the earth under the sun, and our victorious master, Flavius Arcadius the eternal Augustus, Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus, of clarissimus rank, prefect of the sacred praetorium, dedicated (this statue) with the customary devotion, in the time of Antonius Priscus, governor of clarissimus rank.”

“Que la Fortune soit favorable! À l’empereur de la Terre sous le soleil, et notre seigneur victorieux, Flavius Arcadius l’éternel Auguste, Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus, le clarissime préfet du prétoire sacré, avec la dévotion habituelle a consacré (la statue), alors qu’il était gouverneur clarissime Antonius Priscus.”

The column on which the inscription is engraved was found in 1905 by G. Mendel, in the context of the NYU excavations. It was in the West stoa of the South agora and originally located on the South side of the steps that led from the West stoa of the agora to the forecourt of the Hadrianic Baths. Two clamp holes indicate that the column has been repaired. Three further cuttings for clamps suggest the reuse of the monument as a statue base.

The inscription was published for the first time by Mendel in Catalogue des sculptures greques, romaines et byzantines in 1912; then by H. Grégoire in Recueil des inscriptions Grecques Chrétiennes d’Asie Mineure, from Mendel’s copy. L. Robert published the inscription in Hellenica IV, 50-51, whence BE 1949, 178; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity, nr. 26, and Plate VII, whence PHI 661, which has provided the most detailed recent examination of the support and the inscription.

The honorary inscription for the emperor Arcadius was one of a group dedicated to the Theodosian imperial family (see also PPRET 82, 83, 84) and erected by Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus, whose name was erased. The career of this distinguished figure is fully recorded in an inscription from Sidyma in Lycia (PPRET 87). He was made praetorian prefect in the East in 388 AD and fell from power in 392 AD. He suffered damnatio memoriae and banishment to Lycia, but he was rehabilitated posthumously by his grandson with an inscription in Aphrodisia (PPRET 91). Antonius Priscus, governor of the Caria (PLRE I, p. 730), is known only by the series of the three inscriptions dedicated by Tatianus at Aphrodisias (PPRET 82-84).

div.p: ὁ λαμπρότατος ἔπαρχος τοῦ ἱεροῦ πραιτωρίου
